Lid-driven cavity problem

This example demonstrates the solution of the classical lid-driven cavity problem for the incompressible Navier–Stokes equations using MMfem.

The cavity is the unit square Ω = (0,1)², with a moving lid on the top boundary.

Problem setup

  • Domain: unit square

  • Boundary conditions: - Top: horizontal velocity (lid) - Other walls: no-slip

  • Discretization: Taylor–Hood elements

  • Solver: Picard / Newton iterations

Python implementation

The complete Python script is shown below.

  1"""
  2Lid-Driven Cavity Flow Example
  3
  4This script demonstrates how to solve the classic lid-driven cavity problem
  5using MMfem. The problem consists of a square cavity with a moving top wall.
  6
  7Problem setup:
  8    - Domain: [0,1] × [0,1]
  9    - Boundary conditions:
 10        * Top wall (y=1): u = (1, 0) (moving lid)
 11        * Other walls: u = (0, 0) (no-slip)
 12    - Reynolds number: Re = UL/ν = 100 (ν = 0.01)
 13
 14This is a standard benchmark in computational fluid dynamics.
 15"""
 16from netgen import gui
 17from ngsolve import CF, Draw
 18from mmfem import rectangle_mesh, taylor_hood, picard_iteration
 19import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 20
 21
 22def main():
 23    """Run the lid-driven cavity simulation."""
 24    
 25    print("="*70)
 26    print("LID-DRIVEN CAVITY FLOW SIMULATION")
 27    print("="*70)
 28    
 29    # Problem parameters
 30    viscosity = 0.01  # Kinematic viscosity (Re = 100)
 31    h = 0.02          # Mesh size
 32    tolerance = 1e-8  # Convergence tolerance
 33    
 34    print(f"\nProblem Parameters:")
 35    print(f"  Viscosity (ν): {viscosity}")
 36    print(f"  Reynolds number: {1.0 / viscosity}")
 37    print(f"  Mesh size: {h}")
 38    print(f"  Tolerance: {tolerance:.2e}")
 39    
 40    # Step 1: Create mesh
 41    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 42    print("Step 1: Generating mesh...")
 43    mesh = rectangle_mesh(0, 1, 0, 1, h=h)
 44    print(f"  Number of elements: {mesh.ne}")
 45    print(f"  Number of vertices: {mesh.nv}")
 46    
 47    # Step 2: Define finite element space
 48    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 49    print("Step 2: Setting up finite element space...")
 50    X = taylor_hood(mesh, "left|right|bottom|top")
 51    print(f"  Total DOFs: {X.ndof}")
 52    print(f"  Velocity DOFs: {X.components[0].ndof}")
 53    print(f"  Pressure DOFs: {X.components[1].ndof}")
 54    
 55    # Step 3: Define boundary conditions
 56    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 57    print("Step 3: Defining boundary conditions...")
 58    # Moving lid: horizontal velocity = 1
 59    u_bc = CF((1, 0))
 60    print(f"  Dirichlet BC on 'top': u = (1, 0)")
 61    print(f"  No-slip BC on other walls: u = (0, 0)")
 62    
 63    # Step 4: Solve using Picard iteration
 64    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 65    print("Step 4: Solving Navier-Stokes equations...")
 66    
 67    solution, info = picard_iteration(
 68        mesh=mesh,
 69        fespace=X,
 70        dirichlet_boundaries="top",
 71        velocity_bc=u_bc,
 72        viscosity=viscosity,
 73        convection_form="standard",
 74        tolerance=tolerance,
 75        max_iterations=100,
 76        verbose=True
 77    )
 78    
 79    # Step 5: Extract results
 80    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 81    print("Step 5: Extracting results...")
 82    velocity, pressure, _ = solution.components
 83    
 84    # Compute some statistics
 85    from ngsolve import Integrate, sqrt, InnerProduct
 86    
 87    velocity_magnitude = sqrt(InnerProduct(velocity, velocity))
 88    max_velocity = velocity_magnitude(mesh(0.5, 1.0))  # At center of top wall
 89    avg_velocity = Integrate(velocity_magnitude, mesh) / Integrate(1, mesh)
 90    
 91    print(f"  Maximum velocity magnitude: {max_velocity:.6f}")
 92    print(f"  Average velocity magnitude: {avg_velocity:.6f}")
 93    
 94    # Step 6: Visualize results
 95    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 96    print("Step 6: Visualizing results...")
 97    
 98    # Visualize using NGSolve's Draw (opens GUI)
 99    Draw(velocity, mesh, "velocity")
100    Draw(pressure, mesh, "pressure")
101    
102    # Plot convergence history
103    if info['errors']:
104        plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
105        plt.semilogy(info['errors'], 'o-', linewidth=2, markersize=6)
106        plt.xlabel('Iteration', fontsize=12)
107        plt.ylabel('Relative H1 Error', fontsize=12)
108        plt.title('Picard Iteration Convergence', fontsize=14)
109        plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
110        plt.tight_layout()
111        plt.savefig('convergence_history.png', dpi=150)
112        print("  Convergence plot saved to 'convergence_history.png'")
113    
114    # Final summary
115    print("\n" + "="*70)
116    print("SIMULATION COMPLETE")
117    print("="*70)
118    print(f"✓ Converged in {info['iterations']} iterations")
119    print(f"✓ Final error: {info['final_error']:.2e}")
120    print(f"✓ Solution ready for visualization")
121    print("="*70)
122    
123    # Keep GUI open
124    input("\nPress Enter to close visualization and exit...")
125
126
127if __name__ == "__main__":
128    main()
